entry.title: Juneathon Fail!
entry.content:
Well after having a great camping trip at the start of a week holiday, the Lawleys decided to head off camping again.  So I failed to start off Juneathon :(  I have had a great and active June so far, country walks, loads off fresh air and my triathlon training is 6 days a week, so I wont be missing out, but alas I wont be blogging it all.

Good luck to the other Juneathletes!

entry.title: Bedford Sprint Series 1 - 24th April
entry.content:
Thanks to Galeforce events for putting on a great event, it was my first real sprint triathlon - I did one back in 2003 but with no training I don't really count it.

The venue was easy to get to and had ample parking, I was slightly nervous using my new bike rack on the car, but it was great (thanks Halfords!).  I got there with plenty of time to spare, got my transition area sorted.  I noticed lots of people using plastic boxes to carry / store their transition kit in - much easier and tidier than a bag, so I'll do the same next time.  The swimming pool changing rooms were open, but don't really have many facilities - there was always a queue for the gents (pre race jitters I suppose).  I put myself down for a 5:30 swim based on my training the week before, so I had a long wait before starting - over an hour.  A feel laps of the diving pool, did little to calm the nerves.

Swim - 400m (07:00)

I was expecting better from myself in terms of time, but it didn't click, my breathing was laboured and it felt far more tiring than I expected and I was over taken twice, so not great in the end it took me 7 mins to complete.  Not great at all, so next sprint I'll use that time and should get in and started sooner.

Bike - 24k (56:14)

The transition went ok, I decided against putting socks on, so just dried myself quickly, hat on and off.  The swim shorts felt really tight on my legs to begin with and I was worried that the rear tire was low / going flat.  I worried too much, clipped the curb and flew off into the grass / nettles / thistles in the verge - ouch.  I was all in one piece - grazed and had a burning sensation of the nettles but I got back on and got on with the ride.  The ride itself seemed uphill to the A6 then dips and then a short sharp uphill before a downhill into Paversham.  Then a nice downhill and fast on-in.

Run - 5k (25:51)

To me it felt a little shorter than 5k, but I did better than I thought I would and after 26mins I'd finished and felt like a triathlete!


Total Time: 1:31:12

[[posterous-content:BnlvJEcdBlpFhteydDHF]]

Post Tri

Unfortunately, the bike incident hurt more than I realised, my shoulder took the brunt of the fall and ached, but worst of all was the itching from the nettles - took me ages to fall asleep.  Note to self, look where your going when riding the bike!!

entry.title: Day 23 - Muddy and Momentous
entry.content:
Up with the larks this morning to go for my weekly run with Adam. Still very dark in the mornings, so the first off road section was slightly hazardous.  It seems to have got so much muddier in the last two weeks the fields have changed into a quagmire of mud and puddles. So not too dissimilar from last weekend!

The run felt great, in fact managed negative splits.  By the end my legs were so tired I decided a cold bath would help them.   Now for my momentous moment of the day: I managed a cold bath without screaming like a girl!  As my legs were so muddy, I didn't stretch out after the run big mistake as after the cold bath my legs felt too cold to stretch out...

Stats:

Distance: 8:02 mi
Duration: 01:26:28
Avg. Pace: 10:47min/mi

entry.title: Day 17 - Tired legs!
entry.content:
The day after the grim hurt somewhat!  But after sitting in the office chair all day I cycled back to kings cross.  The evening commute feels a much different beast than the morning one, drivers seemed nearer and less careful of cyclists.  Anyway, other than getting a little lost I was a good commute and I think the brief bit of exercise helped rejuvenate the tired muscles.

Back at home I joined a gym only to be told I can't use the gym until I'd done my induction which is scheduled for Thursday, so I was quite miffed.  So I did a lap of the estate in my fastest ever time!  Woot!

entry.title: Day 16 - The Grim
entry.content:
After a week of not running to rest my knee, the day of the grim had arrived and I loved it.

The course was good, lots of puddles and lots you can avoid initially, but wheres the fun in that?  The sooner your feet get wet the quicker you get used to it.  At around 2 miles you couldn't really avoid the puddles - up to about thigh height at this point.  Cold toes dont make for fun running, but you soon get them warmed up and then the later puddles feel refreshing!  Some were strangley warm, probably best not to think about that...

The course was good and around 5 miles there was a real stinker of an obstacle; a cargo net and some excellent mud.  Then into some water, I was in a rut and the water was up to my waist; being 6' 2" I can confirm it was deep!!  Everyone slowed down to tackle that one, so once out I speeded up, but with tired legs and mud on my glasses I tripped and went flying.  Everyone running by checked I was ok and one chap even gave me a score: 8.5 - Not Bad!

At 6 miles I thought only 2 and then in!!  So I speeded up and OMG the last mile - b*stard.  I liked the big dipper hill and finally nearing the end there was some more water, I stepped over a tree trunk and one leg disappeared to my thigh!  Once I struggled out of that, my legs felt like blocks of lead, but it was the on-in.  Into the big final puddle too fast I nearly went flying, out and round the corner and done!

A great event, tough on the legs but a hell of a lot of fun!  I'll be back next year for sure.

Duration: 01:34:52
